Their sweaters have dissolved into threads; the holes I used to count are gone, replaced by a soft bloom of white fuzz that climbs their arms like frost. Their faces are peaceful, mouths slightly open, as if about to tell a secret. I set the skillet down. The cat sits, tail curled over paws, watching. “Hey,” I say. My voice cracks, dry as bark. “Dinner’s ready.” They don’t answer. A bead of clear fluid rolls from Eli’s ear, slips down the curve of the pitcher’s throat, and vanishes. The plant gives a slow, wet swallow. I should leave. I should walk away and let the greenhouse finish its meal. Instead I kneel, brace my elbows on the rim, and reach in. The fuzz is warm, almost feverish. I tug Eli’s shoulder. The flesh beneath is soft as bread left in the rain. My stomach flips—not with nausea, but with hunger. I hate how quickly the thought arrives: stock bones. Pete’s rule echoes: waste nothing. I pull the boning knife from my belt—my knife now, since Pete took the other—and test the edge against my thumb. Dull, but it will do. The cat purrs, a low, approving rumble. I start with the sweaters. They peel away in damp strips, fibres clinging to my fingers. Underneath, the skin is pearlescent, veined with green. I cut carefully, following the seam where shoulder meets neck. The knife slides through with less resistance than chicken skin. No blood, only more of that clear fluid that smells faintly of copper and wet grass. I catch it in the skillet—waste nothing—then stop, ashamed, and lick a drop from the blade. It tastes like the broth in my dream. Mira’s easier; she’s smaller. I lay them side by side on the flagstones, two pale shapes under the dripping glass. Their eyes stay closed. I tell myself they look relieved, like children finally allowed to sleep. I tell myself a lot of things. I joint the limbs the way I used to break down a rabbit: twist until the socket gives, then slice. The elbows pop softly. The knees bend backward, but the tendons part just the same. Each piece I rinse in the runoff from the pitcher plant, pinkish water swirling away. My hands shake, but the knife doesn’t. Muscle memory is a stubborn thing. The cat watches, ears flicking at every sound. When I drop a knuckle-sized piece by its paw, it sniffs, then carries it to the corner to gnaw in private. I line the skillet with the larger cuts—thighs, small of the back—skin-side down. The sap I saved yesterday has thickened; I warm it in my palm until it runs, then drizzle it over the meat. It crackles, caramelises, turns the edges gold. The smell is obscene: Sunday roast, sea breeze, something floral I can’t place. My mouth waters so hard I choke. While the first side sears, I set aside the ribcages. Too small for much meat, but the marrow will melt into anything. I crack them open with the back of the knife, scoop the soft centre into a teacup. It’s pale, almost translucent. I taste a fingertip: buttery, faintly sweet, with an after-note of iron. I eat it standing, straight from the cup, licking the rim clean. The twins’ faces are still there, resting on the flagstones like discarded masks. I cover them with the remains of their sweaters because I can’t look anymore. I flip the pieces. The skin shrinks, tightens, blisters. The sap bubbles up around them, glazing everything in amber. I count eight, nine, ten seconds—longer than I should, but the edges need the burn. When I lift the first piece, it’s crisp, leaking clear juice. I blow once, twice, bite. It gives between my teeth like perfect pork belly, then dissolves into something softer, almost custard. The taste is everything I remember about being safe, and everything I’ve forgotten about being sorry. I eat until the skillet is empty and my stomach aches in a new shape. The cat licks its whiskers, eyes half-closed in feline bliss. I scrape the last glaze with my finger, suck it clean, then run the skillet under the dripping glass until the water runs clear. The bones I pile neatly—small white crescents—beside the pitcher plant. The plant gulps once, as if in gratitude. I sit back on my heels. My hands smell of sap and childhood kitchens. Somewhere inside me, the broth dream stirs again: mother’s ladle, the steam, the folding dark. I wait for tears, but they don’t come. Instead I open Pete’s notebook to a fresh page, write with fingers that leave grease marks: Twins, pitcher plant, glazed in rootwalker sap. Texture: pork belly meets custard. Aftertaste: copper, birthday candles, guilt. I stare at the last word until it blurs. Then I tear the page out, fold it small, and tuck it behind the cat’s ear. It flicks the paper away, unimpressed. The footprints have faded to nothing. The pitcher plant is quiet now, throat slowly closing. I pick up the skillet, heavier than before, and walk back toward the stove. The greenhouse breathes around me, wet and satisfied. Behind me, the small white crescents gleam like teeth in the half-light.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical writing skills but suffers from significant deviations from the established plan and some tonal inconsistencies. The prose is generally well-crafted, with effective sensory details and a maintained atmosphere of dread mixed with desperate hunger. The model successfully captures Mara's character voice and her culinary background, showing her professional knife skills and cooking knowledge even in this horrific context. However, there are several major issues. The chapter fundamentally departs from its planned structure - instead of finding the twins dissolving and scooping broth while humming their lullaby, Mara discovers them already deceased and proceeds to butcher and cook their bodies in graphic detail. This transforms what was meant to be a more subtle, psychologically disturbing scene into explicit body horror. The writing occasionally veers into forced poetry, particularly in passages like "Muscle memory is a stubborn thing" and "The greenhouse breathes around me, wet and satisfied." While some metaphors work well (the pitcher plant "yawning like it's mid-sentence"), others feel overwrought. The characterization of Mara remains consistent with her profile as a former chef, and her internal conflict between hunger and horror is well-portrayed. The cat's behavior aligns with its established personality. However, the twins appear only as corpses, preventing any character development or consistency check. The "cozy horror" tone specified in the prompt becomes strained here - the detailed butchering sequence pushes into territory that feels more like straight horror than the intended blend. The chapter maintains narrative coherence but loses some of the subtle psychological horror that made earlier implied scenes more effective. The dialogue is minimal but natural when present. The writing generally shows rather than tells, particularly in depicting Mara's conflicted emotional state through her actions and physical responses. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 7 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 8 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 6 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 13

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The table is the old potting bench dragged into the center aisle where the light is best—green, leaking, cathedral-bright. I scrubbed it for an hour with palm fronds and my own spit; the wood still smells faintly of fish meal and rot, but the plates fit without wobbling. Three plates only. Pete’s chair is empty, a stump of brick where boots once rested. The twins’ chairs are smaller—upturned plastic crates scrounged from the orchid house. Their names are scratched deep: ELI + MIRA in the same uneven hand that once carved swear words into school desks. I trace the letters with a fingertip, then wipe them clean of sawdust. The terrine waits under a dome of cracked glass. It is the color of dusk just before streetlights come on, shot through with paler ribbons: marrow, fat, maybe memory. I unmold it onto the platter—my best platter, the only platter—and the shape holds: a perfect brick of child. Tiny star-shaped garnishes of shrieker gill crown the corners like misplaced cloves. The glaze—reduced twins and rootwalker sap—shines like varnish on old woodwork. Cat sits at my feet, tail curled, eyes fixed on the brick. I cut a slice for it first, thin enough to see through. It purrs so hard the platter vibrates, then carries its prize under the bench to eat alone. I slice another for me. It slides free with a sigh, edges trembling. On the tongue it is impossibly soft, then faintly resistant, then yielding again—three textures like a story with an unreliable narrator. The taste is Sunday roast, first kiss, and something metallic I can’t name without crying. I chew slowly, letting the flavours separate and recombine. I think of the twins laughing at a joke about farting, the sound echoing like birds. I chew until the thought is gone. I pour the last of the rainwater into teacups. It is cloudy, carries the faint green of dissolved leaf. We used to call it pond-tea and pretend it was gin. I raise my cup to the empty chairs. “To quiet kitchens,” I say aloud. My voice cracks like old fat in a pan. The second slice goes down easier. I don’t bother with the fork anymore; fingers are faster. Grease coats my lips, slides over the scar on my thumb where the mandoline bit me once. I lick it clean. Salt, fat, acid, heat—only the order has changed. Halfway through the terrine the glaze begins to pool, viscous and warm. I tip the platter, watch it run slow as honey, collect it in the chipped teacup. When the cup is full I drink it like broth. It tastes of birthday candles just blown out, of copper pennies held under the tongue, of something ending. My stomach aches in a new place, low and deep, as if it’s making room for more than food. The cat returns, licks the platter clean, then climbs into my lap. Its fur is warm, smells faintly of the same glaze. I stroke it absently, counting vertebrae. Eighteen nineteen twenty. My fingers come away with a dusting of green, fine as talc. I rub it between thumb and forefinger; it smells like wet moss after rain. I open Pete’s notebook to a fresh page. The pencil is down to a nub, so I press hard. Terrine of twins & rootwalker, slow-cooked, pressed under brick. Serves three, eats one. Colour: dusk. Texture: lullaby. Aftertaste: copper, candle smoke, forgiveness withheld. I sign it with my full name—M. Soren—because names feel like anchors tonight. I set the platter aside. There is still meat left, but I’m not hungry anymore. I am something else, stretched tight as sausage casing, glowing faintly from inside. I lean back, listen to the greenhouse breathe. Somewhere a drip counts heartbeats I no longer own. The cat purrs against my ribs; the purr vibrates through bone, through the bench, through the floorboards until the whole place seems to hum the same note. I close my eyes. The taste sits heavy, patient. I wait for the twins to come back, to climb into their crates, to demand seconds. I wait until the plate is cool and the glaze congeals into amber beads that look like eyes. The cat licks one, swallows it whole. Eventually I carry the platter to the broken sink, rinse it under the dribble of rain. The water runs pink, then clear. I set the platter upside down to dry. The terrine brick is gone except for a faint smear shaped like a small handprint. I leave it. I sit on the potting bench, skillet in my lap, and count the green flecks blooming across my forearms. Twenty-seven twenty-eight twenty-nine. They don’t itch. They simply are, like freckles or scars or hunger. I raise the skillet to the empty room. “Seconds?” I ask. No one answers. I smile anyway. The cat jumps onto the bench beside me, nudges the notebook open with its head. A new line has appeared, not in my handwriting: Add a pinch of cinnamon to the glaze next time. Trust me. I laugh, or something close to it. The sound rolls around the greenhouse glass and comes back sweeter, as if someone else laughed first. I lick the last trace of glaze from my thumb and whisper, “Soup’s ready.”
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates sophisticated prose craftsmanship but contains a fundamental structural problem that undermines its effectiveness within the larger work. The writing itself is technically accomplished, with rich sensory details that effectively convey Mara's culinary expertise and psychological deterioration. The author maintains the established voice well - Mara's professional food knowledge bleeds through in phrases like "three textures like a story with an unreliable narrator" and her systematic approach to preparation. The horror builds effectively through the juxtaposition of refined culinary language with the grotesque reality of what's being consumed. However, the chapter completely abandons its planned content. According to the chapter plan, this should focus on the cat bringing a glowing spore-pod that Mara fries with cinnamon, creating a birthday cake smell. Instead, we get an entirely different scenario involving a "terrine of twins" - apparently cannibalism of the child characters Eli and Mira. This represents a wholesale abandonment of the established narrative direction. More problematically, this shift fundamentally alters the story's premise. The original concept centered on the dark irony of delicious spore mutants - creatures that were once threatening enemies becoming sustenance. The cannibalistic turn removes this central tension and replaces it with straightforward horror that feels disconnected from the "cozy-horror" tone established in the prompt. The prose occasionally veers toward purple territory ("cathedral-bright," "viscous and warm") but generally maintains appropriate restraint. Some metaphors land well while others feel overwrought. The emotional register is consistent and the psychological portrait of Mara's transformation is compelling, but it's in service of a narrative that has strayed far from its intended path. The chapter shows strong technical writing ability but fails as a component of the planned story structure. It reads like the author became more interested in exploring cannibalistic horror than following through on the specific mutant-eating premise that was established. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 9 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 2 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 8

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The kettle whistles though there is no fire. I look up from the page—ink still wet, thumbprint in the corner where I pressed too hard. The sound is thin, bird-like, coming from the dark at the far end of the palm court. I set the pencil down. My hand leaves a smear of grease on the paper; the page will remember it. Salt, fat, acid, heat, I breathe. Eight steps to the stove, but the stove is gone, bricks scattered like teeth. I count anyway—one two three—heel-toe around the hole where yesterday’s coals cooled into crust. Four five six—past the place the cat used to sleep, now only a hollow in the moss. Seven eight—kettle. It hangs from a length of wire above the broken drainpipe. No flame beneath it, only the greenhouse warmth gathered all afternoon under glass. Steam threads from the spout, curls, vanishes. Inside, water rocks like a small frightened animal. I lift it. The handle burns. I wrap the apron—once white, now the colour of everything—around the metal and tip the spout. Water pours clear at first, then cloudy, then flecked with green. I catch it in the teacup we used for broth, for sap, for marrow. The cup warms my palms the way hands used to. I drink. It tastes of copper pennies and wet leaves, of the twins’ laughter the day they stacked plates into towers, of Pete humming off-key. It tastes of nothing I have words for, so I swallow and let it settle. Where the water was, a single spore-pod remains. Glowing, walnut-sized, gently pulsing. The kettle shivers as if breathing. I reach in. The pod is warm, alive. I cradle it like an egg I’m afraid to break. A page flutters on the bench—last page of the notebook. My handwriting stops mid-sentence. Below, in shakier ink, someone has added: If anyone finds this, the spoon is under the— The rest is blank. I dig beneath the folded apron. My fingers find the spoon: old steel, blackened at the bowl, handle worn smooth by every mouth that has used it. I weigh it in my palm, thumb brushing the dent where a tooth once chipped. I sit on the potting bench, feet dangling. The greenhouse is quiet except for the drip-drip from the broken pipe and the soft sound of my own chewing—I’ve put the pod in my mouth without deciding to. It pops between molars, releases liquid that tastes like birthday candles just blown out, like sea air before rain, like the first sip of wine I ever stole. A warmth spreads under my ribs, settles behind my eyes, glows. Green freckles brighten along my arms, spreading like moss after rain. They don’t itch. They simply are: new constellations, new recipes written in pigment. I count them—thirty-seven thirty-eight thirty-nine—until the numbers blur. The cat curls around my ankles, purring loud enough to rattle the skillet, but the cat has been gone for days. I scratch anyway; fur meets my fingers, solid as memory. From the shadows, shapes form. Eli and Mira, hands still sticky, sit on their crates. Pete leans against the doorway, thumb-stump wrapped in blue tape gone grey. They don’t speak. They don’t need to. The air carries them, sweet and heavy as glaze. I lift the spoon. “Ready?” I ask. Eli nods. Mira holds out her bowl—no bowl, only palms cupped together. Pete smiles the way he did when the steak came out perfect. I dip the spoon into nothing, lift nothing, and they lean forward as if it were everything. The greenhouse ceiling shimmers. Vines uncurl, lace themselves overhead, fruiting bodies opening like lanterns. Light spills green and gold and soft. The floor beneath me grows warm, pulsing in time with my heartbeat or maybe I am pulsing in time with it. Hard to tell where I end and the greenhouse begins. I write the last line in the notebook with the stub of pencil: Soup’s ready. I set the spoon beside the kettle, blade resting in the dent. The cat—real or not—touches its nose to my wrist once, twice, then walks into the green and vanishes. I leave the potting bench, kettle still warm against my palm. The path is soft now, covered in moss that wasn’t there yesterday. My footprints glow faintly, a breadcrumb trail for whoever comes next. At the doorway I pause, look back. Steam still rises from the spout, curling into letters I can almost read. I close the notebook, tuck it under my arm. The greenhouse exhales, a long satisfied sigh that smells of earth and supper. I step outside—not out, but deeper in—and the door swings shut behind me without a sound. The drip continues. The kettle sings. The soup is almost ready.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter demonstrates strong atmospheric writing and character consistency, successfully concluding the fragmented logbook narrative established in the plan. The piece effectively follows its blueprint, opening with the whistling kettle and incorporating the incomplete sentence about the spoon, building to Mara's apparent transformation through consuming spore matter. The writing maintains Mara's established voice well, incorporating her counting compulsion ("one two three—heel-toe") and her chef's mantra ("Salt, fat, acid, heat"). The sensory details are particularly strong—the taste descriptions of the spore-pod ("birthday candles just blown out, like sea air before rain") feel earned rather than forced, consistent with Mara's culinary background. The atmospheric progression from reality to hallucination/transformation is handled with restraint. The reappearance of dead characters (the twins, Pete, the cat) builds naturally from Mara's isolation and the spore's effects. The greenhouse setting becomes increasingly alive and responsive, creating genuine unease without overwrought horror. However, some metaphorical language occasionally tips toward purple prose. Phrases like "Green freckles brighten along my arms, spreading like moss after rain" and "new constellations, new recipes written in pigment" feel slightly overwrought. The ending sequence, while atmospherically effective, becomes somewhat unclear—it's difficult to parse whether Mara dies, transforms, or simply hallucinates. The chapter successfully maintains the "cozy-horror" balance requested in the prompt, with domestic details (the teacup, the spoon, the familiar kitchen rituals) grounding the increasingly surreal transformation. The horror emerges from bodily change and loss of self rather than external threats. The dialogue is minimal but effective when present, maintaining character voice. The piece shows rather than tells throughout most of its length, letting Mara's actions and sensory experiences convey her mental state. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a sophisticated piece of cozy-horror fiction that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements while delivering genuinely unsettling content wrapped in comforting domestic details. The story follows a clear eight-chapter arc chronicling the protagonist's psychological and physical transformation from reluctant survivor to something else entirely. The strongest elements are the atmospheric world-building and character development. The greenhouse setting feels lived-in and specific, with excellent sensory details that ground the reader in this post-apocalyptic space. The protagonist emerges as a fully realized character through specific details - the cooking background, the habit of tapping thumbnails, the relationship with the cat, and most importantly, the professional cooking language that becomes both comfort and horror as it's applied to increasingly disturbing ingredients. The pacing is expertly handled, with each chapter escalating the stakes while maintaining internal logic. The progression from cooking mushroom creatures to the twins to final transformation feels psychologically realistic rather than forced. The author demonstrates strong technical control, particularly in the use of repetitive phrases ("salt, fat, acid, heat") that become increasingly ominous, and the dripping water that provides a persistent rhythmic background. The horror emerges from the collision between professional culinary language and cannibalistic content, creating genuine unease. The cozy elements - the cat, cooking rituals, domestic details - make the horror more rather than less effective. Character actions remain believable throughout, even as the protagonist's moral boundaries erode. However, the piece occasionally indulges in metaphors that feel slightly forced, particularly in the later chapters where the poetic language sometimes overshadows clarity. Some passages border on purple prose, though they generally serve the atmospheric purposes. The dialogue, while limited, feels natural when it appears. The ending successfully brings the transformation full circle while maintaining the established tone. The story remains faithful to the prompt throughout, delivering both the cozy domestic elements and genuine horror in equal measure. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Pacing: 18 World Building: 19 Compelling Plot: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Coherent: 19 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19
Avg Final Item Score: 87.3/100
+ Victorian Romance — The Upper Window (Chapter Avg: 75.5 | Final: 76.3)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Victorian Romance Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Victorian Romance Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming Characters: - Eliza Fairburn – orphan turned lady's maid, 19, raised in workhouse, learned lock-picking from a reformed thief who ran the Sunday school - Lord Percival Ashcombe – heir to Ashcombe Manor, 28, returned from Grand Tour with debts and a secret engagement to an actress - Mrs. Gwendolyn Ashcombe – dowager countess, 65, sharp-eyed, keeps household accounts locked in her bedchamber - Thomas the footman – 24, secretly teaching himself to read using the library, knows every servant's secret - Rosalind – mysterious woman glimpsed at upper windows, possibly a ghost, possibly Percival's hidden wife - Reverend Mortimer – local vicar, 45, keeps records of every birth and death, knows about Eliza's past - The Clockmaker – unnamed artisan who installed secret panels throughout the manor in 1789, left cryptic blueprints Plot threads: - Eliza discovers evidence that Lord Ashcombe's father was murdered; the proof is hidden in the dowager's locked room - A series of thefts in the village point to someone entering wealthy homes through upper windows - Percival needs to retrieve love letters from his past before his arranged marriage to a duke's daughter - The manor's west wing has been sealed since a fire 20 years ago; strange lights appear at the windows - Eliza's real identity as the legitimate heir to the Ashcombe title, hidden in adoption papers - A cache of smuggled French wine hidden behind a false panel in the nursery - The annual Servants' Ball where everyone's secrets threaten to spill out Tone variations: - Gothic mystery with creeping dread - Romantic comedy of manners with witty banter - Social commentary on class and opportunity - Ghost story where past literally haunts present - Heist narrative where Eliza assembles team of servants Story beats: 1. Opening image: Eliza scaling the ivy to deliver breakfast to hungover Percival 2. Discovery: Finding first clue about the murder while cleaning Percival's room 3. Rising action: Teaching other servants to climb for various reasons 4. Midpoint: First successful entry into dowager's room, finding map of secret passages 5. Complications: Rosalind revealed as Percival's sister, presumed dead 6. Crisis: Eliza's past exposed, dismissed from service, must break in as outsider 7. Climax: Stormy night entry through roof, revelation in burning west wing 8. Resolution: New social order established, windows as gateways to freedom Pacing ideas: - Alternating between Eliza's POV and Percival's to show both upstairs/downstairs - Each chapter focusing on a different window and what it reveals - Slow build of trust between Eliza and Percival - Mirror structure: Chapter 1 and 8 both involve climbing, but with changed stakes Metaphorical uses of windows: - Windows as liminal spaces between worlds (servant/master, past/present) - Glass as both barrier and transparency - Upper windows representing ambition and transgression - Broken windows as fractures in social order # Reflection The prompt "One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows" immediately suggests themes of transgression, hidden knowledge, and the permeability of social boundaries. The most compelling direction seems to blend social commentary with mystery, using the physical act of climbing as a metaphor for social climbing and the crossing of class boundaries. The strongest character concept is Eliza – her position as lady's maid gives her intimate access to the family while remaining invisible, creating natural tension. The orphan-with-secret-past trope works here because Victorian society was obsessed with legitimacy and inheritance. However, we should avoid making her too perfect; her lock-picking skills need a credible origin. Lord Percival as a morally ambiguous romantic lead has potential – his need to retrieve love letters provides immediate plot motivation while his debts create stakes. The idea of him returning from Grand Tour in disgrace is historically accurate and gives him reasons to both need and distrust Eliza. The manor itself should almost be a character – the various windows becoming entry points to different secrets. The sealed west wing provides Gothic atmosphere without needing actual supernatural elements. The Clockmaker's secret panels are historically plausible (18th century was full of such mechanical marvels) and give Eliza skills a practical application. The pacing needs to balance the romance with the mystery. Starting with Eliza already knowing how to climb (hence "quickly learns") skips tedious training sequences. The midpoint revelation about secret passages raises the stakes. The crisis of her dismissal creates the classic "must break into the place that was once home" scenario. The servant team concept feels too modern/heist-like for Victorian setting. Better to keep focus on Eliza and Percival, with Thomas as occasional ally. The ghost angle with Rosalind could work if she's actually alive – a sister hidden away for "hysteria," which was sadly common. The most promising metaphorical layer is windows as representing both opportunity and danger – the higher you climb, the farther you can fall. Each successful entry should reveal not just plot information but character truths. The final image might be Eliza leaving through the front door rather than climbing, but choosing to look back at the windows that once defined her world. Historical accuracy matters: Victorian manor houses did have upper servants' entrances, but accessing them required climbing servants' stairs. Making the window-entry an act of rebellion (avoiding the servant stairs that would take her past Mrs. Ashcombe's watching eyes) gives it purpose beyond mere plot convenience. The romance should develop through shared transgression – each time they work together to access forbidden spaces, they learn to trust each other. Their class difference isn't just obstacle but the central tension: every window crossed is a rule broken.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I will write a short, tightly-plotted Victorian romance-cum-mystery narrated in limited third person that alternates between Eliza Fairburn (19, lady’s maid) and Lord Percival Ashcombe (28, heir). The tone is intimate, urgent, at times gently ironic, never arch; the prose leans on sensory detail and period-appropriate diction without pastiche. The central, literal image is the act of entering a manor through its upper windows; the metaphorical image is the permeability of class and truth. Key choices • One setting—Ashcombe Manor and its immediate grounds—used as a labyrinth whose geography is revealed window by window. • No supernatural elements; apparent “ghost” lights are human agency. • Romantic thread grows through mutual dependence and shared risk, not instalove; class tension remains unresolved until the final chapter. • No ensemble-heist; supporting cast is small and functional (Mrs Ashcombe, Thomas the footman, Reverend Mortimer). • Historical texture is accurate but lightly worn: correct social rituals, dress, speech registers, but story drives the detail, not vice-versa. • Structure is symmetrical: Chapter 1 opens with a climb that is transgressive but practical; Chapter 8 ends with a climb that is ceremonial and liberating. • Each chapter title names the window through which (or toward which) the protagonist moves, giving literal and symbolic focus. Aims • Sustain tension by making every physical ascent mirror an emotional descent into knowledge. • Use weather and time of day as external correlatives for internal stakes. • End with earned optimism: conventions bent, not shattered; love acknowledged, but future left open. Avoid • Melodramatic villainy; Mrs Ashcombe is formidable, not evil. • Gothic cliché (no swoons, no literal ghosts). • Modern sensibilities smuggled into 1888 dialogue. • Overcrowded plot; one inheritance secret, one love-letter packet, one sealed wing suffice. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – The Ivy Casement (Eliza) Eliza climbs the east-wall ivy at dawn to bring Percival his breakfast and discovers a half-burned letter in his grate that speaks of “the night your father fell.” She pockets it instinctively; the art of entering through upper windows is already second nature to her. Establish manor geography, servant hierarchy, and the first prickle of attraction masked as irritation. Chapter 2 – The Nursery Sash (Percival) Percival, nursing gambling debts and an unwanted betrothal to Lady Honoria, returns to the disused nursery to retrieve childhood hiding-places and finds fresh soot on the sill: someone has been searching the chimney. He assumes it is Eliza, confronts her, and learns she is looking for the same thing he is—evidence about the late Lord Ashcombe’s death. Truce declared. Chapter 3 – The Dowager’s Lattice (Eliza) Night. Using a copied key and the ivy-chimney route, Eliza enters Mrs Ashcombe’s locked bedroom window to search for the household account book whose final pages record “extraordinary repairs” to the west wing the week the old lord died. She is nearly caught when the dowager wakes; escape via gutter precipitates a rain-soaked meeting with Percival in the potting-shed. Chapter 4 – The Library Transom (Percival) Percival recalls the Clockmaker’s hidden panel in the library cornice. He and Eliza prise open the high transom window from inside to reach it; inside the panel they find the architect’s original 1789 plans showing a sealed staircase behind the west-wing nursery. Their collaboration shifts from wary to warm; first overt romantic moment—hands held too long over dusty parchment. Chapter 5 – The Staircase Oriel (Eliza) Guided by the plans, the pair force the oriel window that opens onto the forgotten staircase. They discover evidence of a struggle: scorched floorboards, a broken baluster, and a blood-stained ledger page proving the late lord discovered his mother’s embezzlement. Mrs Ashcombe appears, candle in hand; Eliza is dismissed for “insubordination” before Percival can speak. Chapter 6 – The West-Wing Lunette (Percival) Percival, now morally obliged to act, breaks into his own house through the west-wing lunette—the highest, most dangerous climb yet—to retrieve the ledger and confront his mother. He learns the death was accidental: the old lord fell while trying to stop the dowager setting fire to evidence. Guilt, not murder, shadows the house. Chapter 7 – The Servants’ Dormer (Eliza) Dismissed and lodging in the village, Eliza plans one final climb via the servants’ dormer window during the annual Servants’ Ball, intending only to take her belongings. Instead she overhears Reverend Mortimer blackmailing Mrs Ashcombe with forged adoption papers claiming Eliza is the true heir. Percival arrives; together they seize the papers, exposing the vicar and freeing Mrs Ashcombe from her own trap. Chapter 8 – The Front Bay Window (Eliza & Percival) Dawn after the ball. Eliza approaches the manor openly for the first time, but chooses to climb the front bay window—now a deliberate, symbolic act—to return the ledger. Percival waits inside; they acknowledge love but recognise social realities. The chapter—and story—closes with them descending the main staircase side by side, unsure of the future but no longer trapped by the past.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# How a Human Might Approach the Piece A flesh-and-blood writer, confronted with the prompt “One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows,” would probably start with a sensory memory: the sting of ivy rash, the way leaded glass trembles under fingertips, the smell of coal-smoke caught in damp wool. They would let the image sit for days—maybe weeks—before outlining. They might jot single lines on receipts: “thighs burning on brickwork,” “heartbeat so loud it must wake the house.” Only when the climb felt physically present in their own body would they ask, “Who climbs? Why?” The plot would be reverse-engineered from that remembered shiver, not from genre expectations. A human is also likely to leave deliberate gaps. They won’t feel compelled to explain every inheritance law or map every corridor; they’ll trust the reader to intuit the spaces between candle-flame and darkness. They’ll allow characters to contradict themselves, to act from motives that are half-understood even to them. Most importantly, they’ll risk being dull in places—letting a chapter breathe in quiet description—because they aren’t afraid of an algorithmic “engagement score.” # Common LLM Tells and Why They Hurt This Story 1. Safety Padding LLMs default to moral equilibrium: every morally grey action is later justified, every power imbalance is softened. Victorian romance *needs* the raw edge of class—Eliza’s knuckles bleeding on sandstone, Percival’s casual cruelty born of ignorance. If the text rushes to reassure us “but he’s a good master really,” the tension snaps. 2. Tidy Closure The plan already flirts with neatness: adoption papers exposed, lovers united, dowager forgiven. A human might leave Mrs Ashcombe’s guilt ambiguous, or let Percival marry money anyway, because life often pays its debts in coin, not kisses. 3. Impressive Prose Over Physical Truth LLMs reach for “scintillating moonlight” and “lambent shadows.” A human might simply write: “
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I want the story to feel as if someone is whispering it to you in the dark after a long day’s work—plain words, small details that stick, nothing over-explained. The climb is the story; everything else is just what the narrator happened to notice while her knuckles were bleeding. Voice • First-person present, Eliza only. No omniscience, no neat hindsight. She tells what she saw and felt, half of which she still doesn’t understand. • Language is 1888 in cadence, not vocabulary parade: “I tug my skirt free of the ivy” not “I disentangle my bombazine overskirt.” • Sentences breathe—short when she’s hauling herself up, long when she’s hiding and counting heartbeats. Plot choices • One question: Did the old lord fall or was he pushed? Everything else—love, money, freedom—hangs off that single doubt. • Nothing is solved cleanly. Papers turn out to be half-legible, memories contradict, people lie even when they mean to tell the truth. • The romance is not a reward; it’s another risk. They might ruin each other, and they both know it. Stylistic targets • Physical first: cold stone, splinters, the way candle-flame warps in draughts. • Let silence do work: paragraphs where nothing happens except the tick of the hall clock. • End chapters mid-motion, no cliff-hanger punch-lines—just the next breath held. Avoid • Period showroom décor; mention one coal scuttle if she stubs her toe on it, otherwise leave the furniture alone. • Moral balancing. Eliza steals, Percival cowers, Mrs Ashcombe grieves—none of them get absolution handed out like calling cards. • Final-chapter fireworks. The last climb ends in daylight and ordinary voices; the revolution is that nothing collapses. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – The Ivy Ivy rash wakes me before the bell. I climb to the young master’s room because the stair door sticks and Mrs Ashcombe counts steps. While he sleeps I find a scorched corner of letter in the grate: “…if he’d not thrown the lamp…” I pocket it without deciding why. Chapter 2 – The Sash The nursery window is nailed shut since the fire. I pry it with a kitchen knife; the sill is still black with soot. Inside I smell camphor and last winter’s smoke. A child’s slate reads HELP in chalk too fresh to be twenty years old. My hand shakes; the point snaps. Chapter 3 – The Lattice Dowager’s window is latched from within. I hang by the gutter, free a pane with putty softened by rain, and drop onto her carpet like a sack of coals. In the escritoire a ledger shows “repairs, west wing, £300” the week the old lord died. A page is torn out; the knife-edge still raw. Chapter 4 – The Transom Percival catches me on the library ladder, sleeve torn. He doesn’t scold; he holds the lamp while I reach the hidden cornice door. Inside: a child’s tin soldier and a key rusted orange. We say nothing about why both our fathers lied. His thumb brushes mine; it feels like trespass. Chapter 5 – The Staircase Window The sealed door opens with the rusted key. Behind it, stairs sag like old rope. Halfway up, a board gives; I see the drop, feel the air where the banister burned. Percival hauls me back by the wrist. We find a scorched nightshirt cuff still buttoned, still smelling of lavender water. Chapter 6 – The Servants’ Dormer Dismissed for “impertinent curiosity,” I sleep in the potting-shed loft. At ball-night I climb the back gutter, feet bare, dress knotted round my waist. Through the dormer I hear Mrs Ashcombe weeping—not the sound of guilt but of relief. I do not go in. Chapter 7 – The Lunette Storm. Percival climbs after me. We break the west-wing lunette together; rain hisses on ember-black boards. Lightning shows sooty handprints where someone steadied themselves before the fall. We recognise the print—small, left-handed, same as Mrs Ashcombe. Neither of us speaks. Chapter 8 – The Bay Morning. I walk to the front door for the first time, boots squelching. Percival waits on the sill inside. I climb anyway—three feet up the bay ivy—because old habits weigh more than pride. From the ledge I can see the village chimneys, the laundry drying, the future small and uncertain. Percival opens the window; I step through. No bows, no promises. Just two people breathing the same air, wondering how far we can fall and still land on our feet.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Eliza Fairburn Background Workhouse-born in Kent, turned out at fourteen when the matron decided her appetite “outweighed her usefulness.” Spent two winters sleeping in a Canterbury stable, learning to pick locks with a stolen farrier’s nail. A baker’s wife took her in after she mended the oven latch; Eliza still smells dough on her own hands when she’s nervous. Joined the Ashcombe household at seventeen because Mrs Ashcombe liked that she “didn’t talk like gutter.” She can read enough to trace a ledger but spells “window” with two n’s. Personality & Idiosyncrasies Keeps count of every door she’s ever snicked open—seventy-three so far—by tapping her thumbnail against her front teeth. Talks to the house itself: “Easy, girl,” when a hinge groans. Hates the texture of velvet; the nap feels like cat tongues on her calloused fingers. When frightened she recites the Lord’s Prayer backwards, learned from another inmate who swore it warded off beatings. Flaw: curiosity always outweighs caution; she’ll open a sealed envelope before wondering why it was sealed. Physicality Five-foot-two, but her reach seems longer—long arms, rope-wiry from hauling coal scuttles. Hair the color of wet ash, always escaping its pins into damp curls at her temples. Walks toe-first, as if the ground might protest. Eyes grey, not storm-grey, just the grey of slate after rain—steady, unromantic. Hands are a map of nicks and burns; she rubs tallow into the cracks each night, smelling faintly of mutton-fat and lye. Motives & Allegiances Wants enough money to buy one small room with a lock she controls. Secondary: to know why the old lord died—because questions unanswered feel like splinters under skin. Loyal to Thomas the footman, who once smuggled her an extra slice of bread when she had fever. Distrusts Percival, half because he’s gentry, half because she likes the shape of his collarbone. Holds no loyalty to the Ashcombe name; the house is simply a machine whose gears she has learned to oil. Voice Dialogue: “If I wanted charity I’d stand at the church rail. I’d rather owe you a favour—favours can be stolen back.” Internal: *Third stair squeaks like a lying mouse. Count again. One, two, three. Don’t think of the drop. Think of bread, warm bread, crackling crust.* # Lord Percival Ashcombe Background Second son, became heir at twelve when fever took his brother. Sent to Eton where they taught him Latin and to despise feeling sorry. Grand Tour lasted six years, most spent losing at cards in Baden-Baden. Returned with a stack of IOUs, a miniature of an Austrian violinist, and a scar across his ribs from a duel over the violinist’s honor—honour he no longer believes in. Father died the week he came home; guilt tastes like the copper in his mouth when he runs upstairs. Personality & Idiosyncrasies Hums Purcell when anxious, off-key. Cannot bear to watch anyone trim a wick—reminds him of the surgeon who sewed the duel scar. Collects broken pocket-watches but never winds them; likes to imagine time stopped. Flaw: procrastinates until crisis, then acts with reckless speed. Keeps a running tally in his head of every servant’s birthday, but forgets to send the promised half-crown. Physicality Six-foot even, built like a man who fences for show rather than murder. Dark hair refuses pomade; it falls across his forehead when he bows, making him look younger than twenty-eight. Eyes brown, but flecked with amber that catches lamplight when he lies. Dresses carelessly—waistcoat buttoned wrong on mornings after brandy. Moves with the loose-jointed gait of someone always expecting the floor to shift. Motives & Allegiances Needs to clear his debts without marrying money he doesn’t respect. Loves the manor as one loves a sickly sibling—resentful, protective. Protective of Eliza because she reminds him of his brother: small, fierce, breakable. Distrusts his mother’s accounts; suspects she burned more than papers. Loyal to Thomas only so far as a sovereign can buy silence. Voice Dialogue: “A locked drawer is merely a conversation postponed. The house keeps its own minutes.” Internal: *If I stand still the room stops spinning. If I stand still the room stops spinning. Christ, the key is still in my coat—coat is in the hall—hall is full of her.* # Mrs Gwendolyn Ashcombe Background Born a baronet’s daughter, married at nineteen the first man who didn’t bore her. Managed the estate accounts for forty years with a steel nib and no mercy. Lost two children to scarlet fever, one husband to gravity. Has worn black silk so long the dye has turned greenish at the seams. Keeps a locked cashbox labelled “Piano Fund”; inside are pressed violets from her daughter’s coffin. Personality & Idiosyncrasies Counts aloud when walking—always to eleven, then starts again. Reads the household ledger like scripture; a misplaced sixpence is original sin. Keeps a tiny pistol in her workbasket, wrapped in lace. Flaw: equates control with safety; cannot forgive chaos. Smells faintly of camphor and the Parma violets she eats for heartburn. Physicality Tall, spine straight as a fireplace poker. Grey hair coiled so tight it pulls the corners of her eyes. Hands mottled but steady; she signs her name with the same flourish she used at twenty-one. Walks heel-first, cane tapping a metronome against parquet. Voice low, deliberate, cuts off mid-sentence when she hears a door click. Motives & Allegiances Protect the estate at any cost; the land must outlast her grief. Sees Eliza’s questions as termites in the beams. Loyal to the Ashcombe name, not to its living members. Distrusts Percival’s softness; trusts numbers because they do not die. Voice Dialogue: “Dust is simply time settling where it can be measured. Leave it and we drown.” Internal: *Eleven steps to the window. Ten if the carpet wears. Nine if I walk faster than grief.* # Thomas Greaves (footman) Background Son of a Norfolk ostler, left the paddock for polished boots at fifteen. Taught himself letters by comparing the household Bible to the betting slips in the stable yard. Owes Percival six shillings and a favour he never asked for: once, drunk, Percival stood between Thomas and a magistrate’s cane. Has two sisters in service elsewhere; writes to them once a month even though he must borrow words from the newspapers. Personality & Idiosyncrasies Hums sea-shanties while polishing silver; stops abruptly if anyone enters. Keeps a beetle in a matchbox named Admiral. Flaw: cannot keep a secret unless paid twice. Laughs with his teeth closed, as if the sound might spill something valuable. Measures worth in clean shirtfronts and unbroken sleep. Physicality Broad, slope-shouldered; wrists too thick for borrowed livery, cuffs always fraying. Hair the colour of fresh hay, already thinning at twenty-four. Walks heel-toe along hallway seams as if the floor is a tightrope. Eyes blue and direct—he looks at people like he’s taking their measure for a coffin. Motives & Allegiances Wants enough saved to buy a small boat, then a smaller pub. Obeys Mrs Ashcombe because she signs his wages. Bends toward Percival out of remembered kindness. Likes Eliza because she never asks him to read aloud. Voice Dialogue: “Doors don’t close, miss. They just change who’s on which side.” Internal: *Admiral needs air. So do I. One more corridor and I’m owed a swallow of the master’s brandy—fair is fair.*

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Ivy I start counting before my feet leave the ground. One knot in the ivy, two, three—thumb pressed hard into the stem so the sap bleeds green. Dawn is only a suggestion behind the stables, a milky smear that does not yet reach the east wall. The bricks are still warm from yesterday’s sun, but the air is raw enough to nip the sweat on my neck. I climb because the stair door sticks and Mrs Ashcombe counts steps the way other women count rosaries. If I come through the house she will hear, and if she hears she will ask why the young master’s breakfast is late, and if she asks why, I will have to lie. Lying before breakfast leaves a taste worse than tallow. Seven knots. My knee scrapes stone. The ivy smells of cat piss and last night’s rain, a sour green stink that clings to the inside of the nose. I know this stretch by heart: where the mortar crumbles, where a sneeze of lime dust waits for a careless sleeve. My fingers find the groove above the third floor and I haul, toes jammed into a crack meant for pointing, not climbing. The first time I did this I was seventeen and shaking; now it is simply the shortest route between hunger and duty. I swing a leg over the sill and crouch on Percival’s carpet—Turkey red, still showing the ghost of a boot print where he paced last night. The room smells of brandy and candle-fat, the thick sweetish cloud that follows him everywhere. He is sprawled face-down, one arm dangling, shirt rucked to his ribs. The scar there is a pale line with tiny stitch-dots, like dashes in a badly written letter. I have seen it before; I pretend I have not. The tray is heavy—china clinks, the silver dome slides if I tilt—but I set it down quiet as mildew. He does not stir. The grate is cold, yet a single scrap of paper curls among the ashes, edges glowing like a cat’s eye. I hook it with the poker. The paper is thick, expensive, the kind that costs more than my monthly wage. Only three words remain legible, the rest eaten by flame: “…if he’d not thrown the lamp…” Below, a blot of ink where a signature might have been. My heart gives one hard knock against my stays. I fold the fragment into my apron pocket. It crackles like dry leaves. I do not know why I take it; I only know that questions unanswered itch worse than ivy rash. When I straighten, Percival is watching me through half-open eyes the colour of wet peat. His voice is morning-rough. “You’re early.” “Your fire went out,” I say, because fires are safer than letters. He pushes onto an elbow, hair falling across his forehead like spilled ink. “And you climb like a thief.” “I climb like a servant who prefers not to be sacked.” I mean it sharp, but it comes out tired. My palms sting where the ivy bit. He studies me a moment. Something flickers—curiosity, maybe pity—but he only yawns. “Bring coffee. The usual amount of damnation.” I turn to the table. The coffeepot is warm against my wrist. Steam fogs the window, hiding the drop I will face on the way down. Behind me the mattress creaks. I hear the rasp of a match, the small hiss as it takes the candlewick. Then a pause, longer than it ought to be. I glance back. He is holding the poker, staring at the ashes where the letter was. His mouth has gone thin. “Did you see anything odd in the grate?” he asks. “Only ash,” I lie, and the lie tastes of soot. He nods slowly, as if accepting a verdict. I pour coffee black as river mud, and the smell fills the room, pushing out the brandy for a moment. My fingers leave damp prints on the cup. He drinks without looking at me again, but I feel the question settle between us like dust. I leave by the window because the hall is awake now, boots beginning their morning drum. The ivy is wet; water runs inside my sleeve. Halfway down a thorn catches the hem of my apron and rips a sound like tearing paper. I keep climbing. At the bottom I smooth the scrap of letter through the cloth. The ink has smudged further. I can barely make out the last word: “fall.” I tuck it deeper, against the skin above my stays where the heartbeat knocks. Then I walk toward the kitchen, counting knots backwards, the taste of soot still on my tongue.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates sophisticated control of voice, atmosphere, and character development within the Victorian romance framework. The first-person present narration from Eliza's perspective is immediately compelling, establishing her as a practical, observant protagonist with a mysterious past. The author successfully avoids the trap of overwrought period language while maintaining an authentic 1888 cadence. The physical details are particularly well-executed - the ivy that "smells of cat piss and last night's rain," the specific counting of knots, the tactile experience of climbing. These concrete details ground the reader in Eliza's experience without feeling overwrought. The author shows impressive restraint, focusing on sensory details that serve character and plot rather than mere atmospheric decoration. The central mystery element - the burned letter fragment - is introduced organically through Eliza's actions rather than exposition. Her impulsive decision to pocket the evidence feels true to her established character profile as someone whose "curiosity always outweighs caution." The brief dialogue exchange between Eliza and Percival crackles with tension and subtext, revealing class dynamics and mutual wariness while advancing the plot. The characterization aligns well with the provided profiles. Eliza's physical competence, working-class pragmatism, and intuitive distrust of authority come through clearly. Percival's dissolution, his scarred body, and his careful questioning about the letter all match his established background as a second son with secrets. However, there are some minor weaknesses. The phrase "questions unanswered itch worse than ivy rash" feels slightly forced, drawing too much attention to its own cleverness. Additionally, while the Gothic atmosphere is well-established, certain elements like the "ghost of a boot print" verge on overly atmospheric description. The pacing is excellent, building tension through the climbing sequence and culminating in the discovery and subsequent interaction. The author successfully avoids melodrama while maintaining the sense of danger and mystery essential to the genre. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Nursery Sash I wait until the house is at supper, when the clatter of plates covers lesser sins. Mrs Ashcombe keeps the old nursery locked since the night the west wing burned, but locks are only polite suggestions. I carry a kitchen knife wrapped in a rag because metal clinks. My boots are in my hand; the passage flags are cold as pewter under stockings I’ve already darned twice this month. At the bend by the linen press I stop. Laughter floats up—Percival’s and someone else’s, cut short when Mrs Ashcombe coughs. I picture her tapping her cane once for each bite taken. Eleven, then start again. The thought steadies me. I slide the blade between sash and frame and ease the painted nail out of its hole. The wood gives with a sigh like a child caught out of bed. Inside it is darker than any night outside. The curtains are charred along one edge, still hanging because no one could bear to touch them. Air tastes of smoke and camphor and something sweet gone sour. I strike a vesta; the flame shows a rocking horse minus its head, a cradle half-collapsed, and the floorboards bowed toward the place where flames once licked up from below. I smell my own sweat, sharp as onion. I came for a slate they say still shows the child’s last lesson. Superstitious nonsense, but Thomas whispered that soot had been disturbed recently. My shoes leave prints in grey dust that look like small ghosts. The vesta burns my fingers; I drop it. Darkness swells back in. I feel forward until my knuckles strike slate propped against the wall. Light another match. Words are chalked there, letters tall and crooked: HELP. The H is double-lined, as if the writer pressed harder with each breath. It is not twenty years old. Chalk dust powders my fingertips white. I stare until the match gutters. In the flare before it dies I see fingerprints in the soot beside the word—small, left-handed. My own hands shake too much to measure. The floor creaks behind me. I freeze. Another creak. Not the settling of old wood—footfall, careful but heavy. I crouch behind the cradle, heart kicking ribs. A glow widens in the doorway: candle held low. The flame finds my face before I can duck. Percival. He wears evening dress half-buttoned and no cravat; his collar is open at the throat. Candlelight gilds the scar I saw this morning. He studies the slate, then me. “Christ,” he says softly. “You as well.” I stand. My knees pop. “You wrote it?” He shakes his head. “I was coming to scrub it off. Mother sits in there sometimes—” he gestures toward the sealed staircase door—“and I prefer she not see her nightmares spelled out.” I wipe chalk with my sleeve. It smears grey across cambric already ruined. “Someone else was here.” He lowers the candle; shadows stretch our faces long and strange. “Someone small. Servant child?” “Servants don’t come here.” I think of Thomas, but Thomas has hands like spades. I think of Mrs Ashcombe: tall, right-handed. The prints are wrong for both. Percival steps closer. The floor gives a warning groan. He steadies himself on the rocking horse’s neckless stump. “The fire started under this room. They said the lamp fell.” He speaks to the air, not to me. “I always wondered how a lamp walked.” I taste smoke that isn’t there. “The letter this morning—your father threw it?” His mouth tightens. “Half a letter. You read fast.” “I read enough.” We stand in the hush between words, listening to the house breathe. Somewhere below a fork rings against china. I become aware of heat in my pocket: the scrap of paper from his grate. I draw it out. The single word is still legible: fall. He takes it between finger and thumb as if it burns. “I found the rest,” he says. “It says, ‘if he’d not thrown the lamp, I would not have fallen.’ Signed ‘R.’” His voice cracks on the letter like it’s a razor. “R?” I ask. “My sister Rosalind. She was ten when the fire took her.” He looks at me. “They said she ran back for a doll.” The cradle between us sags like a mouth. I think of the footprints, the crooked plea. I think of a child who might have hidden here, afraid to call, chalking instead. I taste metal. Percival pinches the flame out with bare fingers. Darkness is absolute now, but I feel him close, breathing the same charred air. “We need the other half of the letter,” he says. “Before Mother burns the rest.” I nod, forgetting he can’t see. My hand brushes the slate again. The chalk dust is still damp, as if the word were written tonight. Or every night. My skin crawls. “Meet me in the library after supper,” he whispers. “There’s a panel behind the transom. I’ll need someone small.” He moves toward the door. I follow, knife returned to my pocket. On the threshold I glance back. The word HELP is gone, only a faint smudge left, but I feel it beating in the dark like a second heart. Below, Mrs Ashcombe’s cane taps once, twice. Counting. We slip into the corridor before the third.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong atmospheric writing that effectively builds on the established Gothic mystery. The author successfully maintains Eliza's distinctive voice and perspective while advancing the plot through discovery and revelation. The chapter adheres closely to its planned structure, hitting key beats: the knife-pried window, the charred nursery, the mysteriously fresh "HELP" chalked on slate, and the encounter with Percival. The sensory details work well - the taste of "smoke and camphor and something sweet gone sour," the cold flags under stockings, the chalk dust on fingertips. These concrete details ground the scene effectively. Character consistency is strong. Eliza's cautious yet compulsively curious nature aligns with her profile, as does her practical thinking and physical descriptions. Percival's guilt-ridden anxiety and his protective instincts toward his mother feel authentic to his character. The dialogue feels natural without being overly formal or artificially "period." The pacing builds tension effectively, from the careful approach through the house to the discovery of the slate to Percival's unexpected appearance. The revelation about his sister Rosalind and the letter fragment adds compelling depth to the mystery without feeling forced. However, some metaphors occasionally feel slightly overwrought - "darkness swells back in" works, but phrases like "shadows stretch our faces long and strange" verge on purple prose. A few descriptions, while atmospheric, risk becoming self-conscious: "heart kicking ribs" and "taste metal" are effective but border on cliché. The chapter maintains good restraint overall, avoiding melodrama while building genuine suspense. The Gothic atmosphere feels earned rather than imposed, and the romantic tension between Eliza and Percival develops subtly through their shared investigation rather than forced interaction. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 7 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Dowager’s Lattice Moonlight on the sill is thin as skimmed milk. I hang outside the lattice by my fingers and feel the stone gritting under my nails. The ivy stops two feet short of the window; there’s nothing to hold me now but the night air and the habit of falling quietly. I’ve wrapped rags round my boots so they won’t scrape, and the kitchen knife is tucked in my belt like a promise I might not keep. Inside, the room breathes candle-smoke and lavender. Mrs Ashcombe never lets the wick die; she says darkness listens. I can see the flame through the diamond panes, small and steady, as if it has been waiting for me. I pry the blade between frame and sash, feel the latch give with a sigh that sounds too human. Then the window lifts and I’m sliding belly-first onto a rug so thick I leave dust on the pile. The candle is on her escritoire, beside the account book with the red Morocco spine. I’ve dusted that book every Tuesday for two years, but never opened it. She keeps it locked even at night; the key is on a ribbon round her neck. I can see the ribbon, white as a bandage, when she stirs in her bed. I freeze. She lies on her back, hands folded over the counterpane like a corpse laid out. The candle shows every line in her face, carved deep as the cracks in the hearth. Her breathing is shallow, almost inaudible; only the slight rise of the black silk tells me she lives. I count the breaths—one, two, three—until I trust the rhythm. The escritoire drawers are locked too, but the knife finds the weak spot under the lip. Wood splinters softer than bone. I ease the drawer open, finger by finger. Inside: a velvet pouch of sovereigns, a miniature of a child with eyes too large for her face, and the ledger. I take the ledger. It’s heavier than it looks, as if the numbers inside have weight. I open it where the ribbon marks last month. Columns of neat figures march down the page—coal, candles, servants’ wages, the butcher who cheats at weights. Then, halfway down, a line in fresher ink: “Repairs, west wing, £300.” The ink is still glossy, though the entry is dated the week the old lord died. Below it, the page is torn. A jagged edge snags my thumb. I hear the bedsprings creak. I drop behind the escritoire, ledger clutched to my chest. My heart is so loud I’m sure it will wake the dead in the churchyard. Mrs Ashcombe’s cane taps once on the floorboards, like a judge’s gavel. Then silence. I count to eleven, the way she does, and hear her breathing settle again. A draft moves the candle; shadows leap across the walls. I flip backward through the ledger. The same amount—£300—appears every quarter, disguised under different headings: “wine cellar,” “linen, best,” “stabling.” Always torn out the next page. I press my fingertip to the paper; the indent of what was written there is still faint. I can make out an R and what might be a d. I think of Rosalind and the cradle and the word HELP still chalked on my mind. The candle gutters. I need more light, but matches make noise. I carry the ledger to the window and tilt it to the moon. The torn edge glints silver. I touch it, and a thin line of soot comes away on my skin—soot from a chimney that hasn’t drawn for twenty years. My stomach hollows. A floorboard protests behind me. I turn, still crouched, and see Mrs Ashcombe’s eyes open, black in the candle’s halo. She doesn’t speak. She simply looks at me as if I am already a fact she has decided to tolerate. Her hand is on the cane, but she doesn’t lift it. The ribbon with the key rests against her collarbone, rising and falling with each breath. We stay like that, two statues in the half-light. Then she closes her eyes again, slow as a curtain falling. I understand: she knows I am here, and she is allowing me to leave. Permission or trap, I can’t tell. I close the ledger and slide it back into the
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on both the writing prompt and the model's stated plan. Eliza's nocturnal break-in through the dowager's lattice window provides the promised "entering a manor through upper windows" while advancing the central mystery around the old lord's death. The discovery of the doctored ledger entries and torn pages creates genuine intrigue. The writing successfully captures a Victorian Gothic atmosphere without descending into pastiche. The prose style aligns well with the model's stated intention of "1888 in cadence, not vocabulary parade." Phrases like "moonlight on the sill is thin as skimmed milk" and "shadows leap across the walls" create appropriate mood without excessive ornamentation. Character consistency is strong. Eliza's voice matches her established profile - the physical details (calloused hands, careful movements), her criminal skills with locks and knives, and her compulsive curiosity all ring true. The internal counting and prayer-backwards quirks from her profile aren't present here, but that's reasonable given the intense focus required for the break-in. The tension builds effectively through physical details - the gritty stone under fingernails, the careful breathing counts, the creaking floorboards. The scene where Mrs. Ashcombe's eyes open creates genuine suspense, and her silent acknowledgment of Eliza's presence adds psychological complexity. However, there are some weaknesses. Certain metaphors feel strained ("the room breathes candle-smoke" anthropomorphizes awkwardly). The description "eyes black in the candle's halo" borders on purple prose. Most significantly, the chapter cuts off mid-sentence, which appears to be an error rather than an artistic choice, undermining the intended effect. The pacing occasionally stumbles with unnecessary repetition (multiple references to counting breaths and heartbeats). Some transitions feel abrupt, and the discovery of the soot evidence could be more clearly integrated into the narrative flow. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 9 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Library Transom The house is asleep behind shutters when I meet him. Eleven strokes have just shivered the long-case clock in the hall; I counted them from the stairwell where I crouched between the shadows of two suits of armour. My boots are off again—stockings wet through because I forgot to wring the rainwater from my hem. Percival is already in the library, coatless, candle held low so the flame licks only his knuckles. He looks like a boy waiting for a dare. The air smells of beeswax and old paper, with a sour under-note of the brandy he must have carried up from the dining-room. I smell it on his breath when he whispers, “Panel’s above the cornice. I’ll need you on my shoulders.” He says it as if asking me to pass a salt-cellar. I think of the ledger entry, of the soot on my fingertips, and nod. Questions can wait until we are both high enough to be out of ear-shot. He sets the candle on the reading table; its light shows the carpet worn to threads in front of the globe that hasn’t spun true since before I was born. The globe lists a little, like a drunk sailor. I have dusted every continent on it, always wondering why the cartographer coloured the sea such a poisonous green. Tonight I don’t care. Tonight the world is reduced to one narrow bookcase and the space above it. Percival laces his fingers into a stirrup. “Boots off,” I remind him. “You’ll pitch me through the transom if you slip.” He kicks them aside without argument. I set my bare foot in his hands and rise. My knees brush his ears; I feel the tremor in his arms. He is stronger than he looks, but not strong enough to pretend I weigh nothing. My palms find the top shelf—leather spines give under pressure like old fruit. The candle on the table throws my shadow across the ceiling, huge and jagged, as if the house itself were sprouting wings. “Left a bit,” he murmurs. His breath warms my ankle. “There—feel the groove?” I do. A hairline crack in the plaster, no wider than a paper-knife blade. I work the knife in; it meets wood, not brick. A panel, just wide enough for a child’s tin soldier or a folded letter. Another inch, and the blade finds the catch. The panel sighs open, releasing a breath of camphor and something metallic. My fingertips touch cloth first—silk gone brittle—then paper, crisp and sharp-edged. “Got it?” His voice is tight with the strain of holding me. “Hold steady,” I say. My fingers close on a small packet wrapped in faded ribbon the colour of dried blood. Beneath it, something hard and cold—brass, maybe, or bronze. I draw them both out, steadying myself against the cornice. A flake of plaster drifts down and speckles his hair white. He looks up; for a moment we are both children caught stealing biscuits. I slide down him like a ladder. My bare feet meet the carpet, the pile prickling my soles. The packet weighs almost nothing, yet my arms feel heavy. Percival takes the candle, shields the flame with his palm. We move to the table like conspirators in a play. The ribbon knots are stubborn. They give way at last, threads snapping. Inside: three folded sheets, cream laid paper, black ink gone purple with age. The topmost shows a child’s drawing—stick-figure girl holding a lamp larger than her head. Below, in a woman’s hurried hand: “If he’d not thrown the lamp, I would not have fallen. R.” Same hand as the ledger, I think, but younger, frantic. The date is the week of the fire. I feel the hairs rise on my arms. Percival’s finger traces the drawing. “Rosalind,” he says quietly. “She was always drawing lamps. Said they kept the dark from eating her.” He unfolds the second sheet; it is blank. The third is not paper at all but thin copper—an etching of the manor, every room marked. Tiny arrows point to hidden panels, each labelled in the same neat copperplate: nursery, dowager’s chamber, library transom. At the bottom, a signature: “J. Clockmaker, 1789.” The lines are so fine they look scratched by a mouse’s claw. I run my thumb over the etching. The west wing is shown whole, staircase intact. A door is marked with a star. My throat dries. Percival lifts the brass object—an oval watchcase, face cracked. The hands are frozen at a quarter past eleven. He flips it open; inside, no works, only a folded square of paper. He unfolds it with the care of a man defusing a bomb. It is a receipt: “Received from Mrs G. Ashcombe the sum of £300 for services rendered. J. Clockmaker.” The date, again, the week of the fire. The candle gutters. Shadows lurch across the atlas open on the table—Africa swallowing Europe. Percival’s face is pale except for two spots of colour high on his cheekbones. “He was paid to build something,” he says. “A hiding place. Mother knew.” His voice is steady, but the hand holding the paper trembles enough to make the flame dance. I think of the ledger pages torn away. Three hundred pounds, again and again. A child’s chalk plea. A lamp thrown. I think of Mrs Ashcombe’s eyes in the dark, closing like a judge’s ledger. My stomach turns. “We need the staircase,” I say. My voice is smaller than I intend. “The one behind the nursery.” Percival nods. He folds the papers, the watchcase, the ribbon, into his waistcoat pocket. Then he looks at me—really looks—for the first time since I dropped through his window. “You could have taken that receipt to Mother,” he says. “Earned her gratitude.” “I’d rather know what I’m earning first,” I answer. The words taste true. He almost smiles. Almost. The candle spits, and we both start. Somewhere in the wall a rat scuttles.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates solid Victorian atmospheric writing with effective characterization and plot development.
